content: Investments Asked by AnonymousAsked on 09 Aug 2018Any recommendation on which ETFs to invest in for starters? Thank you.6 answersAnswerBump1
Answers (6)Sort By Most UpvoteMost UpvoteMost Recent

Gabriel LeeLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 10 Aug 2018Hi, you can set up a regular savings plan using POSB invest-saver to purchase the Nikko AM Singapore STI ETF or make use of robo-advisors like Stashaway/Autowealth/Smartly to buy US ETFs0 comments2

Kenichi Xi, nᴉʍ oʇ dǝnᴉʇsǝd 不能说的秘密 at Tag Team with Gabriel ThamLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 16 Sep 2018Whenever I see Qs on ETF, i wanna ask back what is the ultimate plan for ETF?​Income?Growth?​Recommending an ETF is easy but making money out of it will depend on the future needs of the person who have a position and the type of strategy applies along the years.​If you are still confuse by now, is better to stick to savings and i will recommend looking at CPF for retirement plan, maybe a good withdrawal at age 55 or just SSB if the amount is less then $100k for now.​Think about it.0 comments1

Jonathan Chia Guangrong, Fund Manager at JCG FundLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 16 Sep 2018If you are new to etfs, consider robo advisory firms that specialise in this, maybe stashaway for a start if you have low amount of funds to start with. Your risk profile will be determined when you create an account and you run through a series of questions on the platform. Once that is done you will be recommended a portfolio to start investing into. Hope this helps 0 comments0

Jay Liu, Diploma in Accountancy  at KHEALevel 6. MasterAnswered on 16 Sep 2018You can consider NikkoAm STI ETF, ABF Bond Index from DBS. If you want to have overseas exposure, you can go with robo-advisors. 0 comments0

Yong Kah HweeLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 15 Sep 2018Nikko AM STI ETF. This tracks the Straits Times Index, which is basically the top 30 stocks in Singapore). You can get it by subscribing to the POSB Regular Savings Plan (RSP). How this works is that you can choose to put X amount of money each month, which the RSP will help you buy a number of units of the ETF. To know more, you can check out this post by Seedly: https://blog.seedly.sg/regular-savings-plan-the-piggy-bank-for-working-adults/​Good luck!0 comments0

Gabriel ThamLevel 8. WizardUpdated on 15 Sep 2018Maybe you can start off with Singapore's ETFs, STI ETF and ABF SG Bond ETF. Both can be bought with min of $100 using Regular Investment Plans such as POSB Invest saver.0 comments0
